desc: The AXIN1 gene encodes Axis Inhibition Protein 1, a key component of the beta-catenin (CTNNB1) destruction complex. Negative regulation of beta-catenin by the complex in the absence of an extracellular stimulus is central to WNT signaling (PMID: 20128690, 23169527). In the complex, AXIN1 and AXIN2 provide scaffolding and bind to the tumor suppressor APC (PMID: 14600025) enabling CTNNB1 destruction (PMID: 9734785). AXIN1 is involved in the TGFβ and SAPK pathways (PMID: 15735151). As part of the AXIN-HIPK2-TP53 complex, the protein also plays a role in the control of cell growth, apoptosis and development (PMID: 15526030). Truncating somatic mutations in this gene, typical of a tumor suppressor, have been associated with hepatocellular carcinoma and hepatoblastomas. Germline mutations in AXIN1 have been associated with gastrointestinal cancers (PMID: 25236910). DNA hypermethylation of the AXIN1 promoter has been associated with caudal duplication anomaly (PMID: 16773576). No drugs targeting the Wnt pathway have yet been approved (PMID: 24981364) although there is some preclinical evidence of disruption of AXIN1 interactions (PMID: 21826110).

desc: AXIN1, a tumor suppressor involved in WNT signaling, is mutated at low frequencies in a diverse range of cancers.
